text: was a old province of Japan in the area of Osaka Prefecture on the island of Honshū.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2002). "Kawachi" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 496. ==History== Kawachi province was established in the 7th century. In the 8th century, Izumi was separated from the older province during the reign of Empress Genshō.Meyners d'Estrey, Guillaume Henry Jean (1884). Annales de l'Extrême Orient et de l'Afrique, Vol. 6, p. 172; excerpt, Genshō crée sept provinces : Idzumi, Noto, Atoa, Iwaki, Iwase, Suwa et Sado en empiétant sur celles de Kawachi, Echizen, Etchū, Kazusa, Mutsu and Shinano In the Meiji period, the provinces of Japan were converted into prefectures. Maps of Japan and Kawachi Province were reformed in the 1870s.Nussbaum, "Provinces and prefectures" at p. 780. ==Shrines and Temples== Hiraoka jinja was the chief Shinto shrine (ichinomiya) of Kawachi. "Nationwide List of Ichinomiya," p. 1 ; retrieved 2012-1-17.
